Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Housing Costs and the Residential Mobility of Middle-Income Renters

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research project will examine how middle-income renters make residential decisions in high-cost cities. This project will focus on the impacts of increased housing costs on middle-income renters and how their perceptions of housing cost change and their experiences of neighborhood change impact their decisions to move or not move. This project will contribute to a growing body of scholarly literature regarding neighborhood change and residential mobility. It will increase basic understanding of population dynamics in urban areas by examining and the reasons that middle-income residents move in a changing city. Because this project will identify the specific factors that influence residential mobility or immobility in middle-income renters, project findings will enable policymakers and housing developers to better understand and serve the needs of middle-income residents in competitive housing markets and will facilitate development of more effective policy interventions aimed at middle-income residents. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award also will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

Many urban areas in the United States have high and increasing housing costs. In the ten years following the 2008 global financial crisis, the number of renters in the United States has increased in every income group, indicating that households who previously would have owned their homes now are renting. The doctoral student conducting this research project will address two specific sets of research questions: (1) How are new housing development, commodification of housing, and increased housing prices related to the spatial distribution of middle-income residents and middle-income affordable rentals? (2) How do housing costs affect middle-income renters' perceptions of housing affordability, provide information about their decisions to move or stay, and impact their experience of neighborhood change? The student will employ a mix of research methods to answer these questions. She will address the first question by analyzing census data to identify spatial relationships between housing investments and middle-income residential locations, she will develop a hedonic model of where middle-income affordable rentals are likely to be. Geographically weighted regression will be used to analyze the geography of the relationship between investment and middle-income locations. The student will address the second question using geo-narratives of residential histories to analyze the spatially and temporally specific reasons for household residential histories. Semi-structured interviews with middle-income residents will provide insights into where they have lived, why they moved or did not move, and how they make sense of the broader processes of housing commodification, investment, and gentrification in their own residential experiences. This study will investigate these questions through a case study in New York City, a high-cost U.S. city, but the findings will be applicable to other high-cost of living metropolitan areas in the United States.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project contributes to advancing knowledge and methodology in geography, urban studies, housing, and urban planning by developing qualitative GIS methods to understand how urban residents make sense of housing cost changes, and how and whether they move because of them. As cities become increasingly polarized and housing costs increase, people may move due to housing cost changes. This project specifically focuses on middle-income renters. As an income group, middle-income Americans are increasingly stretched financially between increased costs of living, increased costs of school and childcare, and relatively stagnant wages. Often seen as gentrifiers moving into urban areas and displacing current residents, this project seeks to understand whether they themselves are moving due to housing cost changes and other forms of gentrification.This project argues that neighborhood change and residential mobility should be considered together, demonstrating how changing characteristics of place impact people staying in or moving from neighborhoods due to anticipated or actual housing cost changes. Using qualitative GIS approaches and semi-structured interviews, this project asks how middle-income renters in New York City make sense of their ability to remain in their housing and neighborhoods and how they perceive urban change impacting their mobility future. Based on the limited possibilities that middle-income renters saw to move near their current home, this project defines the process of “next-move displacement.”

The qualitative GIS approach developed for this analysis applies narrated sketch-mapping to understand perceptions of desirability and affordability for housing and neighborhoods across the landscape of a city. The findings suggest that middle-income renters are not as stably housed as expected. While most informants were able to pay rent on time and remain in their suitable housing, many households live in too-small apartments, forego maintenance in order to keep a low rent, and express concern about the possibility of their landlord raising the rent or selling their unit. They describe themselves as being stuck as renters, most believing it impossible to ever buy housing, and demonstrate that having a higher income does not exclude them from feelings of housing instability. Their view of affordable and desirable places to live in the city reveals a decreasing area of the city where they both want and can afford to live. Paired with perceptions of increasing housing costs around them, they are able to stay in place, but do not believe it is possible to move anywhere nearby. Finally, this project proposes an integrated framework to analyze the temporal relationship between neighborhood housing cost changes and household decisions to remain in place or to move. Synthesizing trajectories of housing histories within changing neighborhood contexts reveals a slow process of being priced out of desired neighborhoods. The findings suggest that middle-income renters may not be able to afford to be long-term renters in New York City, contributing to increased income polarization.


This project provides critical insights into the development of affordable housing for people of a wider range of incomes than are currently supported through non-market policies. It suggests that the relationship between personal finances and housing choices are strong for middle-income urban renters. They are able to make financial tradeoffs between long-term financial plans, like retirement, and immediate goals, like living in a desired neighborhood. However, as housing affordability is a problem in many American cities, the financial obligations of higher-income residents should be taken into account as their cost burden is assessed. Project outcomes and findings were disseminated via multiple outlets including presentations at national and regional conferences and invited talks. A project flyer describing findings was created to distribute to community organizations and neighborhood areas where this project was focused to raise awareness of the hidden challenges of remaining immobile for middle-income renters. Although this project focuses on housing affordability and mobility in New York City for middle-income renters, the methods and concepts developed for this project are applicable to understand the interaction between perceived neighborhood change and individual residential mobility in the U.S and in other countries, particularly as housing affordability continues to be an urban issue throughout the world.
